Contact management Application main¶

async main.healthchecker(db: AsyncSession = Depends(get_db))¶

The healthchecker function is a simple function that checks the health of the database. It does this by executing a SQL query to check if it can connect to the database and retrieve data.

Parameters:

db – AsyncSession: Inject the database session

Returns:

A dictionary with a message

Doc-author:

SergiyRus1974

async main.startup()¶

The startup function is called when the application starts up. It’s a good place to initialize things that are needed by your app, such as database connections.

Returns:

A list of functions to be executed at the end of startup

Contact management Application middlewares¶

class middlewares.CustomHeaderMiddleware(app: Callable[[MutableMapping[str, Any], Callable[[], Awaitable[MutableMapping[str, Any]]], Callable[[MutableMapping[str, Any]], Awaitable[None]]], Awaitable[None]])¶

Bases: BaseHTTPMiddleware

async dispatch(request: Request, call_next)¶

The dispatch function is the first function called when a request comes in. It’s job is to take the request and return a response. It can do this by calling the next middleware in line, or it can handle the request itself.

Parameters:

  • self – Access the class attributes

  • request – Request: Access the request object

  • call_next – Call the next middleware in the chain

Returns:

A response object

Doc-author:

SergiyRus1974

Contact management Application Database¶

class src.database.db.DatabaseSessionManager(url: str)¶

Bases: object

session()¶

The session function is a coroutine that returns an async context manager. The context manager yields a database session, and then closes it when the block exits. If there’s an exception in the block, it rolls back any changes to the session before closing it.

Parameters:

self – Represent the instance of the class

Returns:

A context manager that can be used to manage the session

Doc-author:

SergiyRus1974

async src.database.db.get_db()¶

The get_db function is a coroutine that returns an open database session. It uses the sessionmanager to create a new Session object, and then yields it. The yield from expression calls the __aenter__ method of the Session object, which opens a transaction on the connection pool. When get_db finishes executing, Python automatically calls __aexit__ on the Session object to close it.

Returns:

A session object

Doc-author:

SergiyRus1974

The create_contact function creates a new contact in the database.

  • db – AsyncSession: Pass the database session to the function

  • user – User: Get the user that is currently logged in

A contact object if the contact is created, or none if it already exists

async src.repository.contacts.get_contact(contact_id: int, db: AsyncSession, user: User) → Contact | None¶
The get_contact function takes in a contact_id and returns the Contact object

associated with that id. If no such contact exists, it returns None.

Parameters:

  • contact_id – int: Specify the id of the contact we want to retrieve

  • db – AsyncSession: Pass the database session to the function

  • user – User: Ensure that the user is only able to access their own contacts

Returns:

A contact object if a contact with the given id exists for the given user

Doc-author:

SergiyRus1974

async src.repository.contacts.get_contact_email(email: str, db: AsyncSession, user: User) → Contact | None¶

The get_contact_email function takes in an email and a database session, and returns the contact associated with that email. If no such contact exists, it returns None.

Parameters:

  • email – str: Filter the contact table by email

  • db – AsyncSession: Pass the database session to the function

  • user – User: Filter the query to only return contacts for that user

Returns:

A contact object

SergiyRus1974

async src.repository.contacts.get_contacts_birthday(limit: int, offset: int, db: AsyncSession, user: User) → list[Contact]¶
The get_contacts_birthday function returns a list of contacts whose birthdays are within the next 7 days.

The function takes in three parameters: limit, offset, and db. Limit is an integer that specifies how many contacts to return at once (defaults to 10). Offset is an integer that specifies where in the database to start returning results from (defaults to 0). Db is a SQLAlchemy AsyncSession object which allows us access our database.

Parameters:

  • limit – int: Limit the number of results returned

  • offset – int: Specify the number of records to skip before starting to return rows

  • db – AsyncSession: Pass the database session to the function

  • user – User: Filter the contacts by user

Returns:

A list of contacts that have a birthday in the next 7 days

Doc-author:

SergiyRus1974

  • limit – int: Limit the number of results returned

  • offset – int: Specify the number of rows to skip before starting to return rows

  • user – User: Filter the contacts by user

A list of contacts with the given first name

async src.repository.contacts.update_contact(contact_id: int, body: ContactUpdateSchema, db: AsyncSession, user: User) → Contact | None | bool¶
The update_contact function updates a contact in the database.
Args:

contact_id (int): The id of the contact to update. body (ContactUpdateSchema): A schema containing all fields that can be updated for a Contact object. This is used to validate and deserialize the request body into an object that can be passed as an argument to this function. See schemas/contact_update_schema for more information on what fields are required, optional, etc…

Parameters:

  • contact_id – int: Specify the contact that will be updated

  • body – ContactUpdateSchema: Validate the body of the request

  • db – AsyncSession: Pass the database session to the function

  • user – User: Make sure that the user who is trying to update a contact is the owner of

Returns:

The contact object with the updated fields

Doc-author:

async src.repository.users.update_password(user: User, new_password: str, db: AsyncSession) → User¶

The update_password function takes a user object, a new password string, and an async database session. It updates the user’s password to the new_password string and commits it to the database. It then refreshes the user object from the database so that it has all of its attributes up-to-date.

Parameters:

  • user – User: Pass the user object to the function

  • new_password – str: Pass the new password to the function

  • db – AsyncSession: Pass the database session to the function

Returns:

The updated user

Doc-author:

SergiyRus1974

  • db – AsyncSession: Pass the database session to the function

Contact management ApplicationI routes Auth¶

async src.routes.auth.confirmed_email(token: str, db: AsyncSession = Depends(get_db)) → dict¶
The confirmed_email function is used to confirm a user’s email address.

It takes the token from the URL and uses it to get the user’s email address. The function then checks if there is a user with that email in our database, and if not, returns an error message. If there is a user with that email in our database, we check whether their account has already been confirmed or not. If it has been confirmed already, we return an appropriate message; otherwise we update their account status.

Parameters:

  • token – str: Get the token from the url

  • db – AsyncSession: Get the database session

Returns:

A dict with a message

Doc-author:

SergiyRus1974

async src.routes.auth.login(body: OAuth2PasswordRequestForm = Depends(NoneType), db: AsyncSession = Depends(get_db)) → {}¶
The login function is used to authenticate a user.

It takes in the username and password of the user, and returns an access token if successful. The access token can be used to make authenticated requests.

Parameters:

  • body – OAuth2PasswordRequestForm: Get the username and password from the request body

  • db – AsyncSession: Get the database session

Returns:

A dict with the access token and refresh token

Doc-author:

SergiyRus1974

async src.routes.auth.logout(user: User = Depends(get_current_user), db: AsyncSession = Depends(get_db)) → dict¶

The logout function will logout the user by removing their refresh token from the database.

Parameters:

  • user – User: Get the current user

  • db – AsyncSession: Access the database

Returns:

A response with a dictionary containing the result

Doc-author:

SergiyRus1974

async src.routes.auth.refresh_token(credentials: HTTPAuthorizationCredentials = Security(HTTPBearer), db: AsyncSession = Depends(get_db)) → {}¶

The refresh_token function is used to refresh the access token. It takes in a refresh token and returns a new access_token and refresh_token pair. The function first decodes the given refresh token to get the email of its owner, then it gets that user from the database, checks if their stored tokens match with what was provided, if not it raises an error. If they do match it creates new tokens for them using auth_service’s create functions and updates their stored tokens in the database.

Parameters:

  • credentials – HTTPAuthorizationCredentials: Get the token from the header

  • db – AsyncSession: Get the database session

Returns:

A dict with the access_token, refresh_token and token type

Doc-author:

SergiyRus1974

async src.routes.auth.request_email(body: RequestEmail, background_tasks: BackgroundTasks, request: Request, db: AsyncSession = Depends(get_db)) → dict¶

The request_email function is used to send an email to the user with a link that will allow them to confirm their email address. The function takes in a RequestEmail object, which contains the email of the user who wants to confirm their account. It then checks if there is already a confirmed user with that email address, and if so returns an error message saying as much. If not, it sends an asynchronous task (send_email) containing information about what URL should be sent in order for the user’s account to be confirmed.

Parameters:

  • body – RequestEmail: Get the email from the request body

  • background_tasks – BackgroundTasks: Add a task to the background tasks queue

  • request – Request: Get the base_url of the application

  • db – AsyncSession: Get the database session

Returns:

A dict with a message key and value

Doc-author:

SergiyRus1974

async src.routes.auth.signup(body: UserSchema, background_tasks: BackgroundTasks, request: Request, db: AsyncSession = Depends(get_db)) → dict¶
The signup function creates a new user in the database.

It takes in a UserSchema object, which is validated by pydantic. If the email already exists, it returns an HTTP 409 error code (conflict). Otherwise, it hashes the password and saves to database.

Parameters:

  • body – UserSchema: Validate the request body

  • background_tasks – BackgroundTasks: Add a task to the background tasks queue

  • request – Request: Get the base url of the application

  • db – AsyncSession: Get the database session

Returns:

A dictionary with the user and a message

Doc-author:

SergiyRus1974

  • db – AsyncSession: Pass the database session into the function

The delete_contact function deletes a contact from the database.

The function takes in an integer representing the id of the contact to be deleted, and returns a dictionary containing information about that contact.

  • db – AsyncSession: Pass the database session to the function

async src.routes.contacts.get_all_contacts(limit: int = Query(10), offset: int = Query(0), db: AsyncSession = Depends(get_db), user: User = Depends(get_current_user)) → Sequence[Contact]¶

The get_all_contacts function returns a list of contacts.

Parameters:

  • limit – int: Limit the number of contacts returned

  • ge – Check that the limit is greater than or equal to 10

  • le – Limit the number of contacts returned to a maximum of 500

  • offset – int: Specify the number of records to skip before starting to return the results

  • ge – Check if the value is greater than or equal to 10

  • db – AsyncSession: Get the database session

  • user – User: Get the current user

Returns:

A list of contacts

Doc-author:

SergiyRus1974

  • db – AsyncSession: Get the database session

async src.routes.contacts.get_contacts(limit: int = Query(10), offset: int = Query(0), db: AsyncSession = Depends(get_db), user: User = Depends(get_current_user)) → Sequence[Contact]¶

The get_contacts function returns a list of contacts.

  • limit – int: Limit the number of contacts returned

  • ge – Specify the minimum value of the limit parameter

  • le – Specify the maximum value of the limit parameter

  • offset – int: Specify the offset of the first contact to return

  • ge – Specify a minimum value

  • db – AsyncSession: Get the database session

  • user – User: Get the current user

Returns:

A list of contacts

SergiyRus1974

async src.routes.contacts.get_contacts_birthday(limit: int = Query(10), offset: int = Query(0), db: AsyncSession = Depends(get_db), user: User = Depends(get_current_user)) → Sequence[Contact]¶

The get_contacts_birthday function returns a list of contacts that have birthdays in the next 7 days. The function takes an optional limit and offset parameter to control how many results are returned. The user must be logged in to use this function.

Parameters:

  • limit – int: Limit the number of contacts returned

  • ge – Specify a minimum value, and the le parameter is used to specify a maximum value

  • le – Limit the maximum value of the parameter

  • offset – int: Skip a number of records in the database

  • ge – Set a minimum value for the parameter

  • db – AsyncSession: Get the database session

  • user – User: Get the current user from the auth_service

Returns:

A list of contacts who have a birthday in the current month

Doc-author:

SergiyRus1974

async src.routes.contacts.get_contacts_first_name(first_name: str = Query(PydanticUndefined), limit: int = Query(10), offset: int = Query(0), db: AsyncSession = Depends(get_db), user: User = Depends(get_current_user)) → Sequence[Contact]¶

The get_contacts_first_name function is used to retrieve a list of contacts from the database. The function takes in an optional first_name parameter, which is used to filter the results by first name. The function also takes in two optional parameters: limit and offset, which are used for pagination purposes. If no limit or offset parameters are provided, then the default values will be 10 and 0 respectively.

Parameters:

  • first_name – str: Get the first name from the request

  • min_length – Set the minimum length of a string

  • max_length – Limit the length of the first name

  • limit – int: Limit the number of contacts returned

  • ge – Set a minimum value for the limit parameter

  • le – Limit the amount of contacts returned

  • offset – int: Specify the number of records to skip before starting to return rows

  • ge – Specify a minimum value for the parameter

  • db – AsyncSession: Get the database session

  • user – User: Get the current user

Returns:

A list of contacts

Doc-author:

SergiyRus1974

async src.routes.contacts.get_contacts_last_name(last_name: str = Query(PydanticUndefined), limit: int = Query(10), offset: int = Query(0), db: AsyncSession = Depends(get_db), user: User = Depends(get_current_user)) → Sequence[Contact]¶

The get_contacts_last_name function is used to retrieve a list of contacts with the same last name. The function takes in an optional query parameter called last_name, which is a string that represents the contact’s last name. The function also takes in two optional query parameters called limit and offset, which are integers that represent how many contacts should be returned and where to start returning them from respectively. The function also takes in an optional dependency parameter called db, which represents the database connection pool for asyncpg. Finally, the function takes in an optional dependency parameter called user, which represents the current logged-in user making

Parameters:

  • last_name – str: Get the last name of a contact

  • min_length – Set the minimum length of the last name

  • max_length – Limit the length of the input string

  • limit – int: Limit the number of contacts returned

  • ge – Set a minimum value for the limit parameter

  • le – Limit the number of contacts returned

  • offset – int: Specify the number of records to skip

  • ge – Specify that the limit parameter must be greater than or equal to 10

  • db – AsyncSession: Get the database session

  • user – User: Get the current user

Returns:

A list of contacts with the specified last name

Doc-author:

SergiyRus1974

async src.routes.contacts.update_contact(body: ContactUpdateSchema, contact_id: int = Path(PydanticUndefined), db: AsyncSession = Depends(get_db), user: User = Depends(get_current_user)) → Contact¶
The update_contact function updates a contact in the database.

The function takes an id of the contact to be updated, and a body containing all fields that need to be updated. If no such contact exists, it returns 404 NOT FOUND.

  • body – ContactUpdateSchema: Get the data from the request body

  • contact_id – int: Get the id of the contact to be deleted

  • db – AsyncSession: Get the database session

  • user – User: Get the current user

Returns:

A contact object

Contact management Application routes Users¶

async src.routes.users.forgot_password(body: RequestEmail, background_tasks: BackgroundTasks, request: Request, db: AsyncSession = Depends(get_db)) → dict¶

The forgot_password function is used to send an email to the user with a link that will allow them to reset their password. The function takes in a RequestEmail object, which contains the user’s email address. The function then checks if there is a user associated with that email address and sends an email containing a link for resetting their password.

Parameters:

  • body – RequestEmail: Get the email from the request body

  • background_tasks – BackgroundTasks: Add a task to the background tasks queue

  • request – Request: Get the base_url of the application

  • db – AsyncSession: Get the database session

Returns:

A message to the user that a confirmation email has been sent

Doc-author:

SergiyRus1974

async src.routes.users.read_users_me(current_user: User = Depends(get_current_user))¶
async src.routes.users.reset_password(body: RequestNewPassword, token: str, db: AsyncSession = Depends(get_db)) → dict¶

The reset_password function allows a user to reset their password.

Parameters:

  • body – RequestNewPassword: Get the new password from the request body

  • token – str: Get the token from the url

  • db – AsyncSession: Get the database connection from the dependency injection container

Returns:

A dictionary with a message

Doc-author:

SergiyRus1974

async src.routes.users.update_avatar_user(file: UploadFile = File(PydanticUndefined), current_user: User = Depends(get_current_user), db: AsyncSession = Depends(get_db)) → User¶
The update_avatar_user function is used to update the avatar of a user.

The function takes in an UploadFile object, which is a file that has been uploaded by the client. It also takes in the current_user and db objects as dependencies.

Parameters:

  • file – UploadFile: Get the file that is uploaded by the user

  • current_user – User: Get the current user

  • db – AsyncSession: Get the database session

Returns:

A user object

Doc-author:

SergiyRus1974

class src.services.auth.Auth¶

Bases: object

ALGORITHM = 'HS256'¶
SECRET_KEY = '81ca0de60255b6e2b16b03a717a11c35dc24d8e565fd4f388a876de40d21d9ce'¶
async create_access_token(data: dict, expires_delta: float | None = None)¶
The create_access_token function creates a new access token.
Args:

data (dict): A dictionary containing the claims to be encoded in the JWT. expires_delta (Optional[float]): An optional parameter specifying how long, in seconds, the access token should last before expiring. If not specified, it defaults to 15 minutes.

Parameters:

  • self – Access the class attributes and methods

  • data – dict: Pass in the data that you want to encode into your token

  • expires_delta – Optional[float]: Set the expiration time of the access token

Returns:

A token that is encoded with the user’s id and email

Doc-author:

SergiyRus1974

async create_email_token(data: dict)¶

The create_email_token function takes in a dictionary of data and returns a token. The function creates an expiration date for the token, adds it to the dictionary, and then encodes it using jwt.

Parameters:

  • self – Represent the instance of the class

  • data – dict: Create the token

Returns:

A token which is a string

Doc-author:

SergiyRus1974

async create_refresh_token(data: dict, expires_delta: float | None = None)¶
The create_refresh_token function creates a refresh token for the user.
Args:

data (dict): A dictionary containing the user’s id and username. expires_delta (Optional[float]): The number of seconds until the refresh token expires. Defaults to None, which sets it to 7 days from now.

Parameters:

  • self – Represent the instance of the class

  • data – dict: Pass in the user’s data, which is then encoded into a jwt

  • expires_delta – Optional[float]: Set the expiration time of the refresh token

Returns:

A refresh token

Doc-author:

SergiyRus1974

async decode_refresh_token(refresh_token: str)¶
The decode_refresh_token function takes a refresh token and decodes it.

If the scope is not ‘refresh_token’, then an HTTPException is raised. If the JWTError exception occurs, then an HTTPException is raised.

Parameters:

  • self – Represent the instance of a class

  • refresh_token – str: Pass in the refresh token that is sent from the client

Returns:

The email of the user who has sent the refresh token

Doc-author:

SergiyRus1974

async get_current_user(token: str = Depends(OAuth2PasswordBearer), db: AsyncSession = Depends(get_db))¶
The get_current_user function is a dependency that will be used in the

protected endpoints. It takes a token as an argument and returns the user associated with that token. If no user is found, it raises an exception.

Parameters:

  • self – Access the class attributes

  • token – str: Pass the token that is sent in the authorization header

  • db – AsyncSession: Create a database session

Returns:

The user object associated with the email in the jwt payload

Doc-author:

SergiyRus1974

async get_email_from_token(token: str)¶

The get_email_from_token function takes a token as an argument and returns the email associated with that token. It does this by decoding the JWT using our secret key and algorithm, then returning the subject (sub) field of the payload.

Parameters:

  • self – Represent the instance of the class

  • token – str: Pass in the token that was sent to the user’s email

Returns:

The email from the token

Doc-author:

SergiyRus1974

get_password_hash(password: str) → str¶

The get_password_hash function takes a password as input and returns the hash of that password. The hash is generated using the pwd_context object, which is an instance of Flask-Bcrypt’s Bcrypt class.

Parameters:

  • self – Represent the instance of the class

  • password – str: Specify the password that will be hashed

Returns:

A hashed version of the password

Doc-author:

SergiyRus1974

oauth2_scheme = <fastapi.security.oauth2.OAuth2PasswordBearer object>¶
pwd_context = <CryptContext>¶
verify_password(plain_password, hashed_password) → bool¶

The verify_password function takes a plain-text password and hashed password as arguments. It then uses the pwd_context object to verify that the plain-text password matches the hashed one.

Parameters:

  • self – Represent the instance of the class

  • plain_password – Pass the password that is entered by the user

  • hashed_password – Verify the password

Returns:

A boolean value, true or false

Doc-author:

SergiyRus1974

Contact management Application service Email¶

async src.services.email.send_email(email: EmailStr, username: str, host: str)¶
The send_email function sends an email to the user with a link to confirm their email address.
The function takes in three parameters:

-email: EmailStr, the user’s email address. -username: str, the username of the user who is registering for an account. This will be used in a greeting message. -host: str, this is where we are hosting our application (e.g., http://localhost). This will be used as part of our confirmation link.

Parameters:

  • email – EmailStr: Specify the email address of the recipient

  • username – str: Pass the username to the template

  • host – str: Pass the host name to the template

Returns:

A coroutine, which is an object that represents a function that returns a future

Doc-author:

SergiyRus1974

async src.services.email.send_email_reset_password(email: EmailStr, username: str, host: str)¶
The send_email_reset_password function sends an email to the user with a link to reset their password.
Args:

email (str): The user’s email address. username (str): The username of the user who is requesting a password reset. host (str): The hostname of the server where this function is being called from.

Parameters:

  • email – EmailStr: Specify the email address of the user

  • username – str: Pass the username to the template

  • host – str: Create the link for the user to reset their password

Returns:

A coroutine object

Doc-author:

SergiyRus1974
